text:
SHABANA AZMI: I
grew up believing

that art should be used as an
instrument for social change,

and the work that I
did, particularly when

it comes to the portrayal of
women, where I have actively

turned down roles that show
that it's crucial for women
to be subservient.

I've actually not
done those films,

even when I was
offered a lot of money,

and have done roles
in which I probably
didn't get paid at all.

But I thought that it would
be raising the bar for women

and their rights,
because I think

that it is important to build
up contesting voices because

of the multiplicity
of interests that we
have in a country like India.

So cinema has a
very important role

to play in changing
the mores of society,

particularly when
it comes to women.

Earlier, violence
against women was

portrayed in a way which is
absolutely shameful because it

was-- and within the
mainstream cinema-- where just

the act, for instance, of
rape was so prolonged that it
would become almost vicarious.

The business of cinema is
the business of images.

And how the camera lingers
over the female body

decides whether
it is commodifying
or whether it is sensitizing.

So rape scenes, for
instance, I mean,

there was this
villain who would just
go on for about five minutes.

And it was totally exhausting,
disgusting, and bloodcurdling.

Today, you couldn't
have that in a film.
